titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Donald Clifford Gallup Papers
titlestmt.author: by Danijela True and Diane J. Ducharme

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, research files, personal papers, photographs, printed material and other papers documenting both the professional and personal activities of Donald Gallup as scholarly bibliographer, editor, curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature, and book and manuscript collector on his own account. The majority of the collection consists of Gallup's own papers, including personal, professional and editorial correspondence; a small amount of personal papers; research files; and typescripts and galley proofs of many of his publications, including his editions of the journals of Thornton Wilder and several volumes of works by Eugene O'Neill. Correspondents include the authors James Purdy, Sheri Martinelli, and Mary Bernetta Quinn and the Yale librarian James T. Babb. In addition, the collection contains some of the letters and papers by Modernist writers collected by Gallup personally and donated by him to Yale. The most extensive of these groups is the collection of letters by T. S. Eliot in Group X. Recipients include Arnold Bennett, Richard Cobden-Sanderson, Edgar Jepson, Alida Monro and Harold Monro, Brigit Patmore, John Carroll Perkins, and Donald Gallup himself. Publishers' correspondence and book contracts of Carl Van Vechten are found in Group V., while Group VII. and Group VIII. contain copies of articles and ephemera by and related to Ezra Pound and a small amount of Pound correspondence. Diaries by Carlotta Monterey O'Neill are located in Group X.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into twenty groupings: I. February 1992 Acquisition, 1958-1960. II. July 1986 Acquisition, 1985. III. March 1988 Acquisition, 1988. IV. February 1989 Acquisition, 1953. V. December 1989 Acquisition, 1904-1960. VI. October 1990 Acquisition, 1977-1979. VII. June 1991 Acquisition, 1916-1989. VIII. June 1992 Acquisition, 1909-1963. IX. August 1997 Acquisition, 1944-1976. X. February 2000 Acquisition, 1918-1964. XI. June 2000 Acquisition, 1912-1962. XII. July 2000 Acquisition, 1944-1999. XIII. July 2000 Acquisition, undated. XIV. April 2001 Acquisition, 1866-2000. XV. April 2001 Acquisition, 1754-1979. XVI. June 2001 Acquisition, 1947. XVII. September 2001 Acquisition, 1942. XVIII. May 2008 Acquisition, 1907-2000, XIX. May 2008 Acquisition, 1924-1933, undated. XX. February 1983 Acquisition, 1928- 1979.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 26, 113 - 115 (sound recordings and computer disk): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Donald Clifford Gallup Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Donald Clifford Gallup Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization in 2009, in 2010, and again in 2014. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing. Minor inconsistencies in format, punctuation or abbreviation styles in entries have not been normalized.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Donald Clifford Gallup (1913-2000)
bioghist.p: Donald Clifford Gallup (Yale 1934), literary bibliographer, collector, and curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature for thirty years, was born in Sterling, Connecticut and received his B.A. and Ph.D. in English from Yale University. With the exception of a few years at Southern Methodist University and service in the Army during World War II, Gallup spent his entire career at Yale, first as librarian and then as curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature. In that role he was primarily responsible for building Yale's American Modernist collections, acquiring the archives of Mabel Dodge Luhan, Ezra Pound, H.D., Gertrude Stein, Eugene O'Neill, William Carlos Williams, Josephine Herbst, Mina Loy, and Thornton Wilder. Gallup published full bibliographies of T.S. Eliot (1952) and Ezra Pound (1963), as well as numerous editions of works by the authors whose papers he collected. After his retirement from Yale in 1984, he authored two memoirs: Pigeons on the Granite (1988) and What Mad Pursuits (1998). He died in Branford, Connecticut in September 2000 and bequeathed his papers to the Yale Collection of American Literature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, research files, personal papers, photographs, printed material and other papers documenting both the professional and personal activities of Donald Gallup as scholarly bibliographer, editor, curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature, and book and manuscript collector on his own account. The majority of the collection consists of Gallup's own papers, including personal, professional and editorial correspondence; a small amount of personal papers; research files; and typescripts and galley proofs of many of his publications, including his editions of the journals of Thornton Wilder and several volumes of works by Eugene O'Neill. Correspondents include the authors James Purdy, Sheri Martinelli, and Mary Bernetta Quinn and the Yale librarian James T. Babb. In addition, the collection contains some of the letters and papers by Modernist writers collected by Gallup personally and donated by him to Yale. The most extensive of these groups is the collection of letters by T. S. Eliot in Group X. Recipients include Arnold Bennett, Richard Cobden-Sanderson, Edgar Jepson, Alida Monro and Harold Monro, Brigit Patmore, John Carroll Perkins, and Donald Gallup himself. Publishers' correspondence and book contracts of Carl Van Vechten are found in Group V., while Group VII. and Group VIII. contain copies of articles and ephemera by and related to Ezra Pound and a small amount of Pound correspondence. Diaries by Carlotta Monterey O'Neill are located in Group X.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The February 1982 Acquisition contains correspondence of Donald C.Gallup as well as transcripts, photocopies, and photostats of correspondence and writings of Eugene O'Neill. Writings are typescript drafts and first proofs of O'Neill publications, edited by Donald C. Gallup, including Inscriptions , Poems, 1912-1942 , Work Diary, 1924-1943 , and "The Last Will and Testament of Silverdene Emblem O'Neill." Writings also include first proofs of Donald Gallup's article "Eugene O'Neill's 'The Ancient Mariner'."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The August 1997 Acquisition contains correspondence, printed material, a photograph, writings, notes, curator's files and research files by or relating to Donald Gallup and Gertrude Stein. The correspondence of Donald Gallup consists of professional letters from The New Republic , Liveright, and others regarding the publication of Gertrude Stein's Fernhurst, Q.E.D. and Other Early Writings . The correspondence of Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas contains transcripts of personal letters to friends and family members. The Writings consist chiefly of advance proofs of Flowers of Friendship: Letters Written to Gertrude Stein , edited by Donald Gallup; setting typescript and galley proofs of as well as correspondence relating to Fernhurst, Q.E.D. and Other Early Writings by Gertrude Stein; proofs of Four in America by Gertrude Stein. Other Papers contain newspaper clippings, printed material and card catalogs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The February 2000 Acquisition consists of writings by T.S. Eliot, transcripts of BBC talks, and correspondence. The manuscripts contain setting typescripts and proofs of T.S. Eliot's writings, including The Use of Poetry and the Use of Criticism . BBC Talks consist of typescripts of T. S. Eliot's radio talks on British and European Literature. Correspondence includes letters, Christmas cards, and other ephemera by T. S. Eliot, collected by Donald Gallup. Additionally, the series includes letters from T. S. Eliot to Donald Gallup, Arnold Bennett, R. Cobden-Sanderson, Harold Monro and others.

did.unittitle: Christmas cards sent to Donald Gallup
137a. Special Faber & Faber card designed by Barnett Freedman, signed "T. S. Eliot". With mailing envelope addressed by a secretary
137b. Special Faber card designed by Freedman, signed for Eliot, with a manuscript explanatory note by a secretary.
137c. Special Faber card designed by John Piper, signed "T. S. Eliot". With mailing envelope addressed by a secretary.
137d. Special Faber card designed by Edward Bawden, signed "T. S. Eliot". With mailing envelope addressed by a secretary.
137e. Special Faber card designed by Edward Ardizzone, signed "T. S. Eliot". With mailing envelope addressed by his secretary (later wife), Valerie Fletcher.
137f. Envelope only, addressed by T. S. Eliot. Card not present.
137g. Special Faber card designed by V. H. Drummond, signed "T. S. Eliot".
137h. Special Faber card designed by Robin Jacques, signed "T. S. Eliot". With mailing envelope addressed by Valerie Fletcher.
137i. Special Faber card designed by Alan Howard, signed "T. S. Eliot". With mailing envelope addressed by Valerie Fletcher.
137j. Special Faber card designed by Andre Francois, signed "Tom and Valerie Eliot" ("Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With mailing envelope addressed by a secretary.
137k. Special Faber card designed by Gerald Rose, signed "from Valerie and T. S. Eliot" ("from Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.)
137l. Christmas card reproducing Crivelli's "Madonna della Candeletta," signed "from Valerie and T. S. Eliot" ("from Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With envelope addressed by a secretary.
137m. Christmas card reproducing Memling's "Madonna and Child, Saints and Angels," signed "from Valerie and Tom" ("from Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With envelope addressed by a secretary.
137n. Christmas card reproducing Marino's "Adoration des Mages," signed "from Valerie and Tom Eliot" ("from Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With envelope addressed by a secretary.
137o. Christmas card reproducing Luini's "L'adoration dei Tre Magi", signed "Valerie & Tom" ("Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With envelope with typed address.

137p. Christmas card reproducing Fra Angelico's "The Coronation of the Virgin" (detail), signed "To Donald/ Valerie and Tom" ("To Donald/Valerie" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With envelope addressed by Mrs. Eliot.

137q. Christmas card with printed "Greetings of the Season," explaining that Mr. and Mrs. Eliot are abroad and neither sending nor expecting Christmas cards, but wishing their friends a Happy Christmas and a Joyful New Year, with envelope addressed by a secretary.

137r. Christmas card reproducing Botticelli's "Adoration of the Magi," signed "To Don, from Valerie and Tom" (all except "from Tom" in Mrs. Eliot's manuscript.) With envelope addressed by a secretary.

did.unittitle: 165c. Typed letter, signed: London. Two pages. 25cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With addressed envelope. On the publishing of his biography of Eliot, because of Eliot's objections to Fabers' publishing a book about himself, turned over to Oxford. "If they do not want it, I dare say we shall in spite of my personal protests." Looks forward to seeing the revised version and sends best wishes "for the Mathias cat and yourself."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The April 2001 Acquisition consists of correspondence, research files, writings by Donald Gallup and others, notes, printed material, photographs, sound recordings, and artwork. Correspondence and Subject Files contain personal and professional correspondence, as well as personal and educational files of Donald Gallup. This groups also includes transcripts, photocopies, and photostats of T. S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, Gertrude Stein, and Thornton Wilder correspondence. Other papers consist of research files documenting Gallup's editorial work; transcripts, drafts, and galley proofs of writings by Donald Gallup, including What Mad Pursuits and Pigeons on the Granite ; newspaper clippings and other printed ephemera about or relating to T. S. Eliot; the papers of Townsend Miller; and various publications by Gertrude Stein, Thornton Wilder, and Eugene O'Neill. Printed material consists of published articles by Donald C. Gallup, various exhibition catalogues and bookseller catalogues. Artwork includes a framed pen & wash drawing by John Augustus, as well as framed oil paintings, including "The House I Live in" by Georgia O'Keeffe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The April 2001 Acquistion consists of writings of others, including typescripts of The Journals of Thornton Wilder , edited by Donald Gallup. Printed material contains chiefly bookseller catalogues. Correspondence consists of letters to and from Marianne Moore and James Cabell, as well as third-party correspondence by Djuna Barnes, Marsden Hartley, Lewis Wyndham, Virgil Thomson, and others acquired by Donald Gallup.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The February 1983 Acquisition consists of photocopies of annotated and corrected typescript drafts and of corrected page proofs of Thornton Wilder's American Characteristics and Other Essays (1979). The photocopied material includes copied and original annotations. The essays include the inaugural Charles Eliot Norton lecture at Harvard University, and two subsequent Norton lectures, as well as essays which include Wilder's analyses of the works of James Joyce, Gertrude Stein, Johann Goethe, George Bernard Shaw, and others. Copies of Wilder's introductions to various Gertrude Stein works are also included. Gallup saved typescripts of these works which include revisions, corrections, and notes. Also included are Gallup's typed correspondence with Susan Arterian and Frances Lindley at Harper and Row.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: American Characteristics and Other Essays is a collection of works published in 1979. It includes "Toward an American Language", a Charles Eliot Norton lecture given at Harvard in 1950. That lecture was edited and published in the Atlantic in 1952. The remaining essays included in this collection were written at different points in Wilder's career. Donald Gallup was instrumental in getting the essay collection published. This series contains typescript photocopies of the collection with correspondence about the book and some annotations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Emily Dickinson" is the the third Charles Eliot Norton lecture delivered by Wilder. "Culture in Democracy" was written in English and delivered by Wilder in German when he recived the German Publishers and Booksellers Peace Prize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Goethe and World Literature" was a lecture given by Wilder at the Goethe Convention in Aspen, Colorado in 1949. "James Joyce" was written and pbulished in Poetry, A Magazine of Verse in 1944.

did.unittitle: "Sophocles' Oedipus the King " introduction, "George Bernard Shaw", and The Angel that Troubled the Waters preface

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sophocles' Oedipus the King " is an introduction written for an edition of the play published in 1955. "George Bernard Shaw" was not previously published. The foreword to The Angel that Troubled the Waters and other Plays was published in 1928.

did.unittitle: "A Preface for Our Town ", preface to Three Plays: Our Town, The Skin of Our Teeth, The Matchmaker , "Noting the Nature of Farce", and "Some Thoughts on Playwriting"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "A Preface for Our Town " was written but not published in 1938. The preface to Three Plays: Our Town, The Skin of Our Teeth, The Matchmaker was published in 1957. "Noting the Nature of Farce" was published in 1939. "Some Thoughts on Playwrighting" was published in 1941.

did.unittitle: Richard Beer-Hofmann's Jaakobs Traum , "Frederick J.E. Woodbridge", "Christian Berard", and "John Marin"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Beer-Hofmann's Jaackobs Traum " was published in 1946. "Frederick J. E. Woodbridge" was included in the Commemorative Tributes of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 1905-1941 published in 1941. "John Marin" was part of the Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters .

did.unittitle: "Thomas Mann", "Chauncey Brewster Tinker", and the introduction to "Sir Philip Sassoon's The Third Route "

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Thomas Mann" and "Chauncey Brewster Tinker" were published in the Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters in 1957 and 1964. The introduction to The Third Route was published in 1929.
